coding.display: Clinical data collection/management information system application software (physical object)

Device.manufacturer: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

b659c889-620d-4827-a0a2-d96a583e1574.ExistingAntimicrobialText: The patient has an active prescription for []. Evaluate the dosage and duration to ensure a 60-day regimen of appropriate antibiotic post-anthrax exposure: [].
b659c889-620d-4827-a0a2-d96a583e1574.AllergyAlertText: Potential patient allergy to []. Confirm allergy status.

text.div: Potential patient allergy to latex. The stopper of BioThrax (anthrax vaccine) vial contains latex. Confirm allergy status.

VaccineAdditionalInstructions.text: Epinephrine solution (1:1000) should be available for immediate use in the event that an anaphylactic reaction occurs.

b659c889-620d-4827-a0a2-d96a583e1574.ActivityDefinitionDescription: In 2009, the US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommended in addition to antimicrobial therapy, a 3-dose series of Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed (AVA) BioThrax (Emergent BioSolutions Inc., Rockville, MD, USA) for long-term protection after exposure to anthrax  in individuals without any previous vaccine. After exposure to aerosolized B. anthracis spores, antimicrobial therapy should be initiated as soon as possible. Ideally, the first dose of vaccine should be administered within 10 days. ACIP recommends a post exposure regimen of 60 days of appropriate antimicrobial prophylaxis (covered previously) combined with 3 subcutaneous doses of AVA (administered at 0, 2, and 4 weeks post exposure) as the most effective protection against inhalation anthrax for previously unvaccinated persons aged ≥18 years who have been exposed to aerosolized B. anthracis spores. In general, the peak serologic response to anthrax vaccine occurs 10–14 days after the third dose. (Wright, J.G et al., Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, July 23, 2010 / 59(RR06); 1-30). Additionally, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices subsequently reviewed all safety data available as of March 2008, including the final results of a retrospective study, and concluded that AVA is safe to administer to anthrax-exposed women during pregnancy. In the setting of an anthrax event that poses a high risk for exposure to aerosolized B. anthracis spores, pregnancy is neither a precaution nor a contraindication to vaccination. Pregnant women at risk for inhalation anthrax should receive AVA and antimicrobial drug therapy regardless of pregnancy trimester (Meanye-Delman D et al., Emerg Infect Dis, 20(2), 2014).
b659c889-620d-4827-a0a2-d96a583e1574.ActivityDefinitionPurpose: Provides clinicians with information for quickly assessing individuals exposed to anthrax unrelated to occupational exposure, for example in bioterrorism events, and provides the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen for asymptomatic patients. Includes immediate treatment with antimicrobials and vaccine and follow-up administration of subsequent vaccines to complete the recommended 3-dose vaccination series.
b659c889-620d-4827-a0a2-d96a583e1574.ActivityDefinitionUsage: Intended for use by clinicians caring for individuals ≥18 years of age in an outpatient setting.

Endorser.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

b659c889-620d-4827-a0a2-d96a583e1574.CopyrightStatement: (C) 2018 The MITRE Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

VaccineRequest.name: Anthrax_Post_Exposure_Prophylaxis_Adults_Vaccine_Request
VaccineRequest.title: Anthrax Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for Adults: Vaccine Request
VaccineRequest.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
VaccineRequest.description: In 2009, the US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommended in addition to antimicrobial therapy, a 3-dose series of Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed (AVA) BioThrax (Emergent BioSolutions Inc., Rockville, MD, USA) for long-term protection after exposure to anthrax  in individuals without any previous vaccine. After exposure to aerosolized B. anthracis spores, antimicrobial therapy should be initiated as soon as possible. Ideally, the first dose of vaccine should be administered within 10 days. ACIP recommends a post exposure regimen of 60 days of appropriate antimicrobial prophylaxis (covered previously) combined with 3 subcutaneous doses of AVA (administered at 0, 2, and 4 weeks post exposure) as the most effective protection against inhalation anthrax for previously unvaccinated persons aged ≥18 years who have been exposed to aerosolized B. anthracis spores. In general, the peak serologic response to anthrax vaccine occurs 10–14 days after the third dose. (Wright, J.G et al., Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, July 23, 2010 / 59(RR06); 1-30). Additionally, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices subsequently reviewed all safety data available as of March 2008, including the final results of a retrospective study, and concluded that AVA is safe to administer to anthrax-exposed women during pregnancy. In the setting of an anthrax event that poses a high risk for exposure to aerosolized B. anthracis spores, pregnancy is neither a precaution nor a contraindication to vaccination. Pregnant women at risk for inhalation anthrax should receive AVA and antimicrobial drug therapy regardless of pregnancy trimester (Meanye-Delman D et al., Emerg Infect Dis, 20(2), 2014).
VaccineRequest.purpose: Provides clinicians with information for quickly assessing individuals exposed to anthrax unrelated to occupational exposure, for example in bioterrorism events, and provides the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen for asymptomatic patients. Includes immediate treatment with antimicrobials and vaccine and follow-up administration of subsequent vaccines to complete the recommended 3-dose vaccination series.
VaccineRequest.usage: Intended for use by clinicians caring for individuals ≥18 years of age in an outpatient setting.

endorser.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

VaccineRequest.copyright: (C) 2018 The MITRE Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

additionalInstruction.text: Epinephrine solution (1:1000) should be available for immediate use in the event that an anaphylactic reaction occurs.

CiprofloxacinAdditionalInstructions.text: CONTRAINDICATIONS: Diagnosis of myasthenia gravis and taking tizanidine.

CAUTIONS: If patient is taking  blood thinners, oral antidiabetic drugs, seizure drugs, theophylline, drugs that prolong QT interval, duloxetine (Cymbalta), zolpidem (Ambien), clozapine or any other drug that may interact and cause serious side effects, consider another antibiotic regimen.

ContainedResourcesList.name: Anthrax_Post_Exposure_Prophylaxis_Adults_Vaccine_Request
ContainedResourcesList.title: Anthrax Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for Adults: Vaccine Request
ContainedResourcesList.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
ContainedResourcesList.description: In 2009, the US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommended in addition to antimicrobial therapy, a 3-dose series of Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed (AVA) BioThrax (Emergent BioSolutions Inc., Rockville, MD, USA) for long-term protection after exposure to anthrax  in individuals without any previous vaccine. After exposure to aerosolized B. anthracis spores, antimicrobial therapy should be initiated as soon as possible. Ideally, the first dose of vaccine should be administered within 10 days. ACIP recommends a post exposure regimen of 60 days of appropriate antimicrobial prophylaxis (covered previously) combined with 3 subcutaneous doses of AVA (administered at 0, 2, and 4 weeks post exposure) as the most effective protection against inhalation anthrax for previously unvaccinated persons aged ≥18 years who have been exposed to aerosolized B. anthracis spores. In general, the peak serologic response to anthrax vaccine occurs 10–14 days after the third dose. (Wright, J.G et al., Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, July 23, 2010 / 59(RR06); 1-30). Additionally, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices subsequently reviewed all safety data available as of March 2008, including the final results of a retrospective study, and concluded that AVA is safe to administer to anthrax-exposed women during pregnancy. In the setting of an anthrax event that poses a high risk for exposure to aerosolized B. anthracis spores, pregnancy is neither a precaution nor a contraindication to vaccination. Pregnant women at risk for inhalation anthrax should receive AVA and antimicrobial drug therapy regardless of pregnancy trimester (Meanye-Delman D et al., Emerg Infect Dis, 20(2), 2014).
ContainedResourcesList.purpose: Provides clinicians with information for quickly assessing individuals exposed to anthrax unrelated to occupational exposure, for example in bioterrorism events, and provides the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen for asymptomatic patients. Includes immediate treatment with antimicrobials and vaccine and follow-up administration of subsequent vaccines to complete the recommended 3-dose vaccination series.

OrderSet.name: Anthrax_Post_Exposure_Prophylaxis_Adults
OrderSet.title: Anthrax Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for Adults
OrderSet.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
OrderSet.description: Provides information for treating patients greater than or equal to 18 years old exposed to anthrax within the past 60 days, who do not have anthrax. It is divided into two parts: \n- Part #1: For patients that may be symptomatic to flag the need to conduct a full diagnostic evaluation to rule out anthrax before proceeding with post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) \n- Part #2: For patients  who are  asymptomatic (not displaying signs and symptoms of anthrax), it provides recommended PEP regimen
OrderSet.purpose: Provides clinicians with information for quickly assessing individuals exposed to anthrax unrelated to occupational exposure, for example in bioterrorism events, and provides the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen for asymptomatic patients. Includes immediate treatment with antimicrobials and vaccine and follow-up administration of subsequent vaccines to complete the recommended 3-dose vaccination series.
OrderSet.usage: Intended for use by clinicians caring for individuals ≥18 years of age in an outpatient setting.

endorser.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

OrderSet.copyright: (C) 2018 The MITRE Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

contained.name: Anthrax_Post_Exposure_Prophylaxis_Adults_Ciprofloxacin_Request
contained.title: Anthrax Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for Adults: Ciprofloxacin Request
contained.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
contained.description: In 2009, the US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommended in addition to antimicrobial therapy, a 3-dose series of Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed (AVA) BioThrax (Emergent BioSolutions Inc., Rockville, MD, USA) for long-term protection after exposure to anthrax  in individuals without any previous vaccine. Includes immediate treatment with antimicrobials and vaccine and follow-up administration of subsequent vaccines to complete the recommended 3-dose vaccination series.

endorser.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

contained.copyright: (C) 2018 The MITRE Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

additionalInstruction.text: CONTRAINDICATIONS: Diagnosis of myasthenia gravis and taking tizanidine.

CAUTIONS: If patient is taking  blood thinners, oral antidiabetic drugs, seizure drugs, theophylline, drugs that prolong QT interval, duloxetine (Cymbalta), zolpidem (Ambien), clozapine or any other drug that may interact and cause serious side effects, consider another antibiotic regimen.

dosage.patientInstruction: Take with full glass of water
